ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about modern technology and the workings of politics behind these technologies.

Learned about the interaction of climate change and current technology + energy efficient alternatives (electric vehicles, solar power, co-generation power plants, etc.) and different types of electric communications (fiber optic, computers, biomedical research, etc.). Developed intuition on how legislative policy lags behind technological innovations.
I learned a lot of interesting things about a wide variety of topics. Very interesting class.
I developed skills in presenting, adapting to broad regions of study, and learned so much about multiple interesting fields of science.
Learned about several modern technologies and how exactly they work

I learned more about the different types of modern technologies: their advantages, disadvantages, and how they affect policy making in several cities and countries. For instance, I gained insight into why solar cars aren't so widespread aside the fact they are expensive.
I learned that science is not something that I am interested in pursuing and a professor can really shape a course.

I learned a variety of practical and relevant sciences in both breadth and depth. I learned a lot about sciences from electricity and atomic makeup to MRI technology. I also practiced reading research papers for my final project.
I gained basic, surface-level knowledge about a number of different scientific topicselectricity and solar cars, fiber optics, historical ways of how the internet worked, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength is that the course is a relatively low-workload class despite it teaching students essential things. The weakness is that some concepts were brushed over too quickly; this may have been a me problem though, because I did not have much training in science during high school.

Strengths: Material is very approachable (especially for non-STEM majors) yet relevant to modern-day. Second half of the semester is spent learning from guest experts in various fields.

Weaknesses: Class is poorly organized; if you miss a class, it is not recorded and lecture talks provide information not adequately covered in slides. Midterm was a time-crunch, even if you knew all the content going in beforehand. Grading is very confusing and not transparent at all (done using a GPA conversion that is poorly explained and implemented). Although Professor Prober is an expert in his field, many times he would interrupt guest lecturers to comment on his own accomplishments which came off as quite rude. PSets were busy-work on content that was not properly introduced in class (but the TA was very helpful!!).
Strengths: First half of term lectures were very interesting and informative; weaknesses: second half of term guest lectures were a bit hit-or-miss and sometimes very boring.
The grading disparity for the psets was a bit difficult but otherwise fantastic class.
Excellent science credit if you have some prior knowledge of the history of various modern technologies over the past 80 years.

Strengths: it was cool to have guest lectures, problem sets were frontloaded so not bad at all, final project was great, no final exam - overall definitely a good gut science class
Weaknesses: classes often went far too deep into how the different technologies worked, even though a lot of the concepts weren't on the midterm, as a result it was easy to space out in a lot of lectures

I think this class exposes students to the various fields in STEM, from bio technology, to energy related technology to social and technical issues associated with machine learning algorithms. There were several guest lecturers who came in to explain several modern technologies and policies and how they apply in the real world. Weakness: it's easy to zone out during discussions / lectures.
I think that Professor Prober makes the course very manageable in the workload but fails to make the content interesting.
Unfair grading TA

Strengths:
- Detailed lectures
- Friendly professor

Weaknesses:
- Lectures could be more engaging and related to each other

This is not the most interesting class, partially due to the material but also partially due to Professor Prober's droning voice. The class is a gut in the sense that the material is not that difficult. The workload however, is quite unnecessary. Your grade is determined by a few psets, your midterm, and your final presentation. All of the psets are to be completed before the midterm, so the first half of the semester is comprised of doing a ton of work while the second half of the semester is comprised of doing very very little work. The class would be better suited if this work was spread out more.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Sure. Workload is manageable3 psets, one midterm, and one final presentation (on science topic of your choice). However, lectures can be rather dull, and many students were not engaged. The second half of the semester is very light and just requires class attendance at guest lecture presentations and completion of the final project.
Good science gut.
Absolutely, such a fun first year seminar and got to connect with my peers and learn cool things.
Yeshumanities majors, take this class to get your science credit
Yes, definitely a gut science class with frontloaded work and an easy and interesting final project - if you're a non-stem major, absolutely go for it
Yes, I would. I think it's a good exposure of the various fields in STEM, especially to students who aren't considering pursuing STEM.
I would recommend this course only if a student is looking for a light workload and enjoys science, otherwise I would not recommend this course.

I might recommend this course to someone who doesn't want a high workload class for their Sciences credit, as well as someone who wants to learn about a variety of science topics without spending too much time on a single one.
